Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: One Step Direct Deposition of Durable Cathode for High Temperature Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award will enable scientific inquiry and realization of innovative manufacturing methods to deposit new catalyst and electrode structures onto high temperature proton exchange membranes. The approach taken in this work will allow for independent control over compositional and structural parameters in a single flame-based reactive spray deposition step, significantly reducing the number of manufacturing steps that are required with traditional processes. This will enable high performing proton exchange membrane fuel cells to be produced at low manufacturing cost. In this work, the team will quantify the impact of processing conditions on the catalyst and electrode structure, and will use this information to discover the fundamental limits to which processing can push activity. To accomplish this, the team will study the influence of processing parameters on particle formation, catalyst utilization and morphology. Additionally, the influence of the support and electrode layer thickness on catalyst utilization and durability will be studied. Electrochemical characterization of the high surface area catalysts will be performed on three levels: catalyst, ex-situ electrodes, and in-situ electrodes. This information will be used to study the electrochemical Thiele modulus as a design tool for oxygen reduction electrocatalysts. Educationally, this grant will provide high school students and teachers as well as undergraduate and graduate students with hands-on experience and training in the fields of sustainable energy, manufacturing and electrochemical engineering. The grant will also provide opportunities for student internships in industry with the industrial partner Sonalysts.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in the electrochemical activity and catalyst utilization of commercial-scale electrodes. This research will also provide critical structure-property information for the rational design of next-generation structures. This research will also focus on bridging laboratory-scale discovery and large scale catalyst nanomanufacturing, allowing for rapid implementation by our industrial partner, Sonalysts. Implementation and scale-up of the structure-property information will further reduce the cost and improve the performance stability of electroactive materials in several platforms. Immediate commercial derivatives of the proposed project include: a novel, scalable catalyst synthesis process; formulations for high temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells; and hybrid fuel-cell battery submersibles. Although this project is focused on fuel cells, the results can be implemented toward batteries, sensors and catalysts in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most critical breakthroughs that is needed to broadly implement proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) – a clean energy source – for mobile and stationary applications is the discovery of electrodes with low noble metal loading and high stability.  The primary pain point from a stability perspective is the Pt cathode, which was the focus of this project.  Degradation of electrodes with low catalyst loading not only reduces the electrochemical surface area (ECSA), but does so disproportionately at the cathode/membrane interface where most of the oxygen reduction reaction occurs. Therefore, new electrode structures and processing pathways are needed to produce high stability electrodes. 

In this project, our team advanced Reactive Spray Deposition Technology (RSDT), a flame-based approach that has the flexibility to produce materials of multiple chemistries (metals, oxides, etc.) with precise structural control.  We were able to create a new gradient cathode design that did not significantly degrade during PEMFC operation.  Hence, high fuel cell performance was maintained.  The transformative nature of our work was in two areas.  First, our team synthesized and characterized a new class of gradient structure electrocatalysts, with controlled ionomer to carbon ratio, I/C, with very high activity and materials stability. Catalyst coated membranes with gradient cathodes were fabricated by RSDT at UConn with an extremely low Pt loading of 0.05 mg cm-2 at the anode and 0.1 mg cm-2 at the cathode.   Second, we developed a modeling tool to predict the performance of the catalyst layer and assist in gaining a fundamental understanding of the structural parameters that have the greatest influence on the electrode performance and degradation. These advances were broadly disseminated to the scientific community through the publication of 22 papers that acknowledged the NSF award, as well as 18 presentations at international conferences and PI Dr. Maric presented as an invited, keynote speaker at eight conferences.

In addition to the scientific contributions above, our team worked diligently to increase the opportunities for under-represented groups and to provide training across a wide range of experiences levels.  Six undergraduate students, three of which were female, were trained to work on this project. Five UConn graduate students and three graduate students from Politechnico di Milano (Polimi) in Italy worked on this project.  Two of the Polimi students spent one full year at UConn, while the third was at UConn for a period of three months.  The Polimi students were added to the project as a result of a deep collaboration between our team and Dr. Andrea Casalegno that developed during the project period.  In exchange for the Polimi students that spent time at UConn, three UConn students are spending the summer of 2018 at Politechnico di Milano.  Finally, both professors Maric and Mustain offered intensive summer research and professional development experience to the Joule Fellows teachers for three years.  The Joule Fellows program at UConn specifically targets teachers from underserved districts to promote educational opportunity among minority communities.

Also as a result of this project, an automotive manufacturing company has signed a research collaboration with Polimi and UConn to further explore the RSDT developed by Dr. Maric as a feasible technology for Proton Exchange Membranes Manufacturing.  Finally, this NSF GOALI project provided the opportunity for UConn students to work with fuel cell companies and participate in internships during the summer. This was a great learning experience for the students to gain hands-on experience translating fundamental knowledge and experimental work from the classroom and lab to the manufacturing labs and activities relating to scaling up the technology.

Modified by: Radenka Maric

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: One of the most critical breakthroughs that is needed to broadly implement proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) – a clean energy source – for mobile and stationary applications is the discovery of electrodes with low noble metal loading and high stability. The primary pain point from a stability perspective is the Pt cathode, which was the focus of this project. Degradation of electrodes with low catalyst loading not only reduces the electrochemical surface area (ECSA), but does so disproportionately at the cathode/membrane interface where most of the oxygen reduction reaction occurs. Therefore, new electrode structures and processing pathways are needed to produce high stability electrodes. In this project, our team advanced Reactive Spray Deposition Technology (RSDT), a flame-based approach that has the flexibility to produce materials of multiple chemistries (metals, oxides, etc.) with precise structural control. We were able to create a new gradient cathode design that did not significantly degrade during PEMFC operation. Hence, high fuel cell performance was maintained. The transformative nature of our work was in two areas. First, our team synthesized and characterized a new class of gradient structure electrocatalysts, with controlled ionomer to carbon ratio, I/C, with very high activity and materials stability. Catalyst coated membranes with gradient cathodes were fabricated by RSDT at UConn with an extremely low Pt loading of 0.05 mg cm-2 at the anode and 0.1 mg cm-2 at the cathode. Second, we developed a modeling tool to predict the performance of the catalyst layer and assist in gaining a fundamental understanding of the structural parameters that have the greatest influence on the electrode performance and degradation. These advances were broadly disseminated to the scientific community through the publication of 22 papers that acknowledged the NSF award, as well as 18 presentations at international conferences and PI Dr. Maric presented as an invited, keynote speaker at eight conferences. In addition to the scientific contributions above, our team worked diligently to increase the opportunities for under-represented groups and to provide training across a wide range of experiences levels. Six undergraduate students, three of which were female, were trained to work on this project. Five UConn graduate students and three graduate students from Politechnico di Milano (Polimi) in Italy worked on this project. Two of the Polimi students spent one full year at UConn, while the third was at UConn for a period of three months. The Polimi students were added to the project as a result of a deep collaboration between our team and Dr. Andrea Casalegno that developed during the project period. In exchange for the Polimi students that spent time at UConn, three UConn students are spending the summer of 2018 at Politechnico di Milano. Finally, both professors Maric and Mustain offered intensive summer research and professional development experience to the Joule Fellows teachers for three years. The Joule Fellows program at UConn specifically targets teachers from underserved districts to promote educational opportunity among minority communities. Also as a result of this project, an automotive manufacturing company has signed a research collaboration with Polimi and UConn to further explore the RSDT developed by Dr. Maric as a feasible technology for Proton Exchange Membranes Manufacturing. Finally, this NSF GOALI project provided the opportunity for UConn students to work with fuel cell companies and participate in internships during the summer. This was a great learning experience for the students to gain hands-on experience translating fundamental knowledge and experimental work from the classroom and lab to the manufacturing labs and activities relating to scaling up the technology.
